required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Tissue Collection for Drug Screening and Bioanalysis
clinical_study.official_title: Tissue Collection for Drug Screening and Bioanalysis

lead_sponsor.agency: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

clinical_study.source: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to improve upon the knowledge currently available about pediatric central nervous system (CNS) tumors by further examining tissue, blood, and saliva samples from consenting patients. Parents of patients with CNS tumor may also be asked to provide saliva samples for analysis.

detailed_description.textblock:
The goal of this project is to enable the acquisition of tissue available for research with the prospect of enabling the development of new therapeutic avenues for patients diagnosed with cancer in the central nervous system.
During the patient's routine operative procedure, if extra tissue deemed unnecessary for diagnostic or clinical purposes is available, selected samples will undergo DNA and/or RNA extraction and integrity analysis, whole genome and RNA sequencing, DNA and RNA methylome analyses, proteomic analysis, immunoprofiling, and primary culturing of the tumor cells. These cultures will then be used for drug screenings and to create patient-derived xenografts.

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluating and characterizing the genetic, immunohistochemical, cellular, and molecular profiles of pediatric neoplastic lesions
primary_outcome.description: To develop patient-derived tissue cell lines and xenografts

study_pop.textblock: Pediatric and adult patients with a central nervous system tumors. Parents of patients with CNS tumors.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Suspected neoplastic central nervous system (CNS) lesions
- Undergoing a neurosurgical procedure to remove CNS tissue and/or tumors associated with this tissue
- Tissue available in excess of that required for diagnostic or clinical purposes
May also include:
- Parent of patient with CNS lesion

overall_official.affiliation: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

reference.citation: Rajappa P, Cobb WS, Vartanian E, Huang Y, Daly L, Hoffman C, Zhang J, Shen B, Yanowitch R, Garg K, Cisse B, Haddock S, Huse J, Pisapia DJ, Chan TA, Lyden DC, Bromberg JF, Greenfield JP. Malignant Astrocytic Tumor Progression Potentiated by JAK-mediated Recruitment of Myeloid Cells. Clin Cancer Res. 2017 Jun 15;23(12):3109-3119. doi: 10.1158/1078-0432.CCR-16-1508. Epub 2016 Dec 30.
